facts.text: These are appeals by certificate

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J. These are appeals by certificate. They are by the same appellant and they raise companymon question of law.

facts.text: They are by the same appellant

facts.text: The appellant is a partnership firm

anchor.surface_text: Before examining that companytention, it is necessary to set out the, relevant facts. The appellant is a partnership firm. It carries on business as dealers in

facts.text: It carries on business as dealers in groundnuts, oil seeds and Arhar

anchor.surface_text: It carries on business as dealers in roundnuts, oil seeds and Arhar. For the assessment years 1965-66, 1966-67, the Sales-tax Officer, Rampur assessed the

facts.text: For the assessment years 1965-66, 1966-67, the Sales-tax Officer, Rampur assessed the appellant

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1965-66, 1966-67, the Sales-tax Officer, Rampur assessed the appellant to sales-tax on the turnover of the groundnuts oil manufactured by the appellant and to purchase tax on the turnover of the oil seeds and foodgrains.

facts.text: assessed the appellant to sales-tax on the turnover of the groundnuts oil manufactured by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: the appellant to sales-tax on the turnover of the groundnuts oil manufactured by the appellant and to purchase tax on the turnover of the oil seeds and foodgrains. The appellant unsuccessfully appealed against the assessment orders. Thereafter it

facts.text: to purchase tax on the turnover of the oil seeds and foodgrains

anchor.surface_text: and to purchase tax on the turnover of the oil seeds and foodgrains. The appellant unsuccessfully appealed against the assessment orders. Thereafter it took up the matter in revision before the revising authority.

facts.text: The appellant unsuccessfully appealed against the assessment orders

anchor.surface_text: The appellant unsuccessfully appealed against the assessment orders. Thereafter it took up the matter in revision before the revising authority. There, again it substantially failed.

facts.text: it took up the matter in revision before the revising authority. There, again it substantially failed

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter it took up the matter in revision before the revising authority. There, again it substantially failed. Aggrieved by that decision, he moved the High Court of Allahabad for a writ of certiorari quashing the levy of purchase tax

facts.text: moved the High Court of Allahabad for a writ of certiorari quashing the levy of purchase tax imposed on him in respect of his purchases of oil seeds

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that decision, he moved the High Court of Allahabad for a writ of certiorari quashing the levy of purchase tax imposed on him in respect of his purchases of oil seeds. The High Court rejected those petitions. Hence these appeals.

facts.text: The High Court rejected those petitions

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected those petitions. Hence these appeals. We shall number extract the impugned numberification to the extent, it is material for the purpose of this appeal.

facts.text: with effect from October 1, 1964, the turnover of first purchases in respect of oilseeds shall be liable to tax under Section 3-D at 2 paisa per rupee

anchor.surface_text: Not. No. ST-7122/X-99 16 64 dated October 1, 1964. In exercise of the powers under sub-section  1  of section 3-D of the Uttar Pradesh Sales Tax Act, 1948  U.P. Act No. XV of 1948 , the Governor of Uttar Pradesh is pleased to numberify that with effect from October 1, 1964, the turnover of first purchases in respect of goods mentioned below shall be liable to tax under Section 3-D of the said Act. ------------------------------------------------------------ SI. Name of goods Rate of tax. NO. ------------------------------------------------------------- Foodgrains including cereals and pulses1 .5 paisa per rupee Gur 3 paisa per rupee Oilseeds 2 paisa per rupee

facts.text: Section 3AA was incorporated into the Act on April 1, 1956

anchor.surface_text: This section was incorporated into the Act on April 1, 1956. Under this section, on the goods specified therein, sales tax number, exceeding the maximum rate for the time being specified in s. 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 can be levied by the StateGovernment on the turnover in respect of sales by dealers to the companysumers.

facts.text: S. 3-D was incorporated into the Act on August 1, 1958

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that S. 3-D was incorporated into the, Act on August 1, 1958. The companytention on behalf of the appellant was that s. 3AA is a special provision regarding certain specified class of goods including oil seeds whereas S. 3-D is a general provision.

facts.text: We have companysidered the first ground of attack in Civil Appeals, Nos. 362 and 1692 of 1969

anchor.surface_text: We have companysidered the first ground of attack in Civil Appeals, Nos. 362 and 1692 of 1969  Mls. Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal etc. v. State of U.P.  in which we have delivered judgment just number. For the reasons mentioned therein, the companytention that S. 3-D 1  is ultra vires the Constitution fails.

facts.text: The High Court of Allahabad has companysistently taken the view that it is open to the State Government to levy purchase tax in exercise of its powers under S. 3-D even in respect of goods companyered by S. 3AA

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad has companysistently taken the view that it is open to the State Government to levy purchase tax in exercise of its powers under S. 3-D even in respect of goods companyered by S. 3AA. We are in agreement with that view.

issues.text: Whether Section 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 is ultra vires the Constitution because excessive legislative power had been delegated to the State Government and because it discriminates between registered dealers who made purchases through licensed dealers and those through unlicensed dealers

anchor.surface_text: The first contention urged was that Section 3-D 1  of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  is ultra vires the Constitution, firstly because that under that section excessive legislative power had been delegated to the State Government and secondly on the ground that it discriminates between the registered dealers who made their purchases through licensed dealers and the registered-. dealers who made their purchases through dealers who are number licensed.

issues.text: Whether notification No. ST-7122/X-900 16 64 dated October 1, 1964 issued under S. 3-D(1) of the Act imposing purchase tax on oil seeds is invalid as it contravenes S. 3AA of the Act

anchor.surface_text: notification No. ST- 7122/X-900 16 64 dated October 1, 1964 issued under S. 3- D 1  of the Act imposing purchase tax on oil seeds is invalidas it contravenes S. 3AA of the Act. We have considered the first ground of attack in Civil Appeals, Nos. 362 and 1692 of 1969  Mls. Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal etc. v. State of U.P.

issues.text: Whether the notification referred to earlier is violative of s. 3AA of the Act

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned therein, the contention that S. 3-D 1  is ultra vires the Constitution fails. The only surviving question is whether the numberification re- ferred to earlier is violative of s. 3AA of the Act. Before examining that contention, it is necessary to set out the, relevant facts.

issues.text: Whether S. 3AA as a special provision excludes the application of S. 3-D as a general provision in respect of oil seeds

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant was that s. 3AA is a special provision regarding certain specified class of goods including oil seeds whereas S. 3-D is a general provision. Hence dealings in respect of oil seeds must be held to be governed exclusively by s. 3AA. In support of his contention, the learned ,Counsel for the appellant called into, aid the rule of construction that a special provision excludes the application of a general provision.

issues.text: Whether sub-section (4) of S. 3-D provides that on the issue of a notification under it, no tax shall be levied under any other section including S. 3AA in respect of the goods so notified

anchor.surface_text: On the issue of a notification under this section no tax shall be levied under any other section in respect of the goods so notified. The provisions of the second and third proviso to Section 3 and of Section 18, shall mutatis mutandis apply in relation to the tax payable under this Section.

issues.text: Whether the non-obstante clause in S. 3AA overrides S. 3-D

anchor.surface_text: The non-obstante clause does not take in S. 3-D. If the legislature intended to exclude the operation of S. 3-D, in respect of matters covered by S. 3AA, nothing would have been easier than to say so.

holdings.text: it is open to the State Government to levy purchase tax in exercise of its powers under S. 3-D even in respect of goods covered by S. 3AA

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.3-D(4) has wide amplitude overriding other sections; S.3-D later enactment; non-obstante in S.3AA excludes only S.3 and 3A; agrees with High Court
